top_categories.workout_context: Migration Gravel Race’s 404-mile distance demands power production deep into fatigue — the defining challenge of ultra-distance gravel.
Every session at Migration Gravel Race intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Migration Gravel Race’s red volcanic dust and savanna trails and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Racing Migration Gravel Race isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Migration Gravel Race’s red volcanic dust, hard-packed savanna trails demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
At 404 miles, Migration Gravel Race rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Migration Gravel Race when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Migration Gravel Race’s 26,000ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Migration Gravel Race rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Migration Gravel Race’s red volcanic dust and savanna trails delivers on race day.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Migration Gravel Race. Make this intensity feel like home.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Migration Gravel Race — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.

race_overlay.heat: June in Maasai Mara, Kenya — 15-30°C (59-86°F), equatorial sun, possible afternoon storms. Heat + altitude combination that compounds daily. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Migration Gravel Race — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day. Race-day realities: Equatorial sun at altitude; Heat + UV + altitude = dehydration risk that compounds daily.
race_overlay.nutrition: Ultra-distance fueling for 404 miles: 80–100g carbs/hour from mile 1 — don’t wait until you’re hungry. Practice your exact race-day nutrition in every long training ride. Carry backup calories. 404 miles burns 8,000–12,000+ calories — you cannot replace them all, but you must try.
race_overlay.altitude: Migration Gravel Race with 26,000ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Equatorial sun at altitude; Heat + UV + altitude = dehydration risk that compounds daily.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Migration Gravel Race requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on red volcanic dust and savanna trails to build confidence. Expect: red volcanic dust, hard-packed savanna trails, game reserve roads.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, Endurance, and VO2max to prepare you for 404 miles of red volcanic dust and savanna trails in Maasai Mara, Kenya.
